name: Whole-Cell Analysis
description: Many ways of characterizing the function of an engineered organism can be performed on intact cells.  Typically these involve fluorescent reporter genes or growth-based assays.

contents.params: Today we're discussing Whole-Cell Analyses.  These are the methods used to extract information about a genetic composition starting with intact cells. We'll discuss demonstration experiments, whole-cell assays, and experimental design.
A demonstration experiment involves testing a system in a context close to its real-world usage in a manner that highlights the its features, and demonstrates the absence of undesirable features.
The most commonly used whole-cell assay involves the measurement of fluorescence.

Biochemical assays involve the quantification of specific biochemicals or the monitoring of specific biochemical reactions in a cell. The image here is of a mouse embryo in which the lacZ protein is produced in developing cells of the spinal cord. LacZ is one of the biochemical reactions that can be easily monitored using one of these assays.  The compound Xgal will turn blue in its presence allowing the staining of cells that express it.
Microbiological assays are whole cell assays that monitor some non-chemical process in the cell, such as cell growth, adhesion, and swarming.

Thus far we've focused on describing different ways of extracting information about the function of a genetic device in a cell.  There are additional considerations such as the choice of controls and choice of experimental conditions that must be including in the Test phase.  We'll describe 4 specific areas of information one needs to extract from an assay.  In differential expression, you are comparing a strain's function under two or more environmental conditions.  In a transfer function, you are continuously varying some environmental parameter and trying to produce a function relating the output behavior to this input.  Dynamics involves following the system over time with your assay.  Finally, population heterogeneity involves performing your assay on individual members of the cell population.

pages.name: Caltech Researchers Find Pulsating Response to Stress in Bacteria

contents.params: Researchers at the California Institute of Technology have found a new kind of stress response in a bacterial species called B. subtilis. Instead of just shifting from one steady state to another and staying there, the cells deal with stress—such as the lack of food—by activating a regulatory protein in steady pulses. The cell cranks up the frequency of the pulses if there's more stress. By attaching fluorescent proteins to the genetic circuit responsible for B. subtilis's stress response, the researchers can observe each pulse as a green flash. This video shows the pulsating cells as they multiply over the course of more than 12 hours. To read more on the research, go to http://media.caltech.edu/press_releases/13470. (Credit: Caltech/Elowitz Lab.)
